page.title: 16Plantlife on the Saugh Hill
page.content: On the slopes of the Saugh Hill, above the Girvan Valley, soils are thin and acidic. Low growing plants found on the lower slopes include{sorrel, {tormentil, bilberry, milkwort and {birds foot trefoil.}The most dominant of the taller plants is{gorse}which produces a yellow, almond-scented flower in June. Higher up on the hill most plants are very low growing and include{ling {heather, cotton grass and matgrass.} The latter is the result of overgrazing the better grasses with sheep which ignore the coarse matgrass. Because of the heavier rainfall on the summit there are many boggy areas in which{sphagnum moss, polytrichum {moss and bogstitchwort}thrive.
